title: Waiting for a Covid-19 Vaccine, and Worrying About It
description: Readers discuss how to persuade people to take it and how to decide who gets it first, but also fear insufficient testing to ensure its safety.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: Seoul Will Investigate #MeToo Accusations Against Dead Mayor
description: A fact-finding team will have no power to subpoena or indict anyone, but women’s rights activists and the mayor’s accuser have called for an investigation anyway.
content: SEOUL, South Korea — Seoul City Hall officials said on Wednesday that they would create a joint fact-finding team with women’s groups and legal and human rights experts to investigate accusations that Mayor Park Won-soon had sexually abused a secretary for four years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: U.S. Asylum Officers Denounce Trump Proposal That Would Block Asylum Claims
description: The union representing federal asylum officers submitted official comments calling the Trump administration’s plan “extreme” and “draconian.”
content: WASHINGTON — A Trump administration plan to overhaul the asylum system in the United States would subject vulnerable families to danger and violate international law, officers who would carry out the policy said Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Schwartz
title: A Heat Wave, the Coronavirus: Double Spikes of Risk Hit Communities
description: The South and Southwest hit record temperatures over the weekend and meteorologists warned that heat will rise in the East and High Plains.
content: For much of the United States, the last several days have been brutal: record temperatures recorded around the country, and coronavirus case numbers are on the rise as well, complicating efforts to protect people at risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben S. Bernanke
title: Ben Bernanke: I Was Chairman of the Federal Reserve. Save the States.
description: Congress must act decisively to avoid repeating mistakes of the recovery from the Great Recession.
content: The coronavirus pandemic has set loose a recession of shocking speed and severity. In the coming months, the actions taken by both the public and the private sectors will have economic and public health repercussions that will reverberate for years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Zimmer
title: Covid-19 Risk Doesn’t Depend (Much) on Blood Type, New Studies Find
description: New studies show that people with Type A blood are not at greater risk of getting sick, as previous studies had suggested.
content: Early in the Covid-19 pandemic, researchers found preliminary evidence suggesting that people’s blood type might be an important risk factor — both for being infected by the virus and for falling dangerously ill.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Estrin
title: Their Workers Kept Being Stopped by the Police, So They Decided to Help
description: A  restaurant with Black employees is prioritizing its workers’ mental health as they navigate the coronavirus and the protests against racial injustice.
content: The employees of Grandchamps, a Haitian restaurant in the Bedford-Stuyvesant neighborhood of Brooklyn, were closing up after a long, hot day of filling takeout orders in early June when the owners asked them to gather in the dining area.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Rasgon
title: The Tahini War: The Food at the Center of an Arab Gay Rights Battle
description: After an Arab tahini magnate donated to an Israeli gay rights group, her company faced a boycott. But gay activists say the controversy has an upside.
content: TEL AVIV — When Julia Zaher, the owner of a company that makes some of the most popular tahini in Israel, made a donation to an Israeli gay rights group recently, she saw it as an unremarkable act.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Taylor Trudon
title: Teenage Angst, Revisited in Isolation
description: Those who moved back to their childhood bedrooms during quarantine are finding more than just N’Sync posters.
content: When Meera Parat decided to leave her one-bedroom apartment in Seattle and return to her childhood home in Palo Alto, Calif., she figured she would be staying for a few weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Alter and Elizabeth A. Harris
title: In Publishing, ‘Everything Is Up for Change’
description: A wave of deaths and retirements prompted publishers to name new leaders. Now the industry is in a rare moment of transformation that promises to influence the books put out into the world.
content: Getting to the top in book publishing has traditionally been a plodding and prolonged climb — and once you got there, you didn’t leave. Knopf has had four publishers in its 105-year history. Farrar, Straus and Giroux has only been run by two people since John C. Farrar, Roger W. Straus and Robert Giroux.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bakalar
title: Eating Fish May Protect the Brain From Pollutants
description: Women with the highest levels of omega-3s, found in fish, had less brain shrinkage tied to air pollution.
content: Eating fish could help protect the brain against the detrimental effects of air pollution, a new study suggests.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: Theater Streams See Stars Pop Up in Unexpected Places
description: Most of them are available on short notice, after all. Live readings with some of the New Group’s original casts and an Ian Dury jukebox musical are among this week’s highlights.
content: One of theater’s great pleasures is watching actors bring characters to life. The era of online performing arts has added a remarkably democratic element by allowing high-caliber casts to pop up in everything from revisited classics to fresh-from-the-oven efforts by young playwrights. Most stars are available on short notice these days, after all, and now they can take on projects that time or financial constraints may have kept them away from. We look for whatever upside we can find, and the pleasure of fine acting in an unexpected setting has been a balm.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Roach
title: Yes, It’s Already Time to Buy Bulbs for Fall Planting
description: But there are a few things to consider before you go shopping.
content: Shopping for flower bulbs: It’s one of the more joyful summertime garden chores, certainly better than dragging hoses and sprinklers around or keeping ahead of the most incorrigible weeds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Adam Newman
title: It’s Long Past Time to Get That Beard Under Control
description: Good thing men are warming up to some new tools.
content: Some men working from home and growing beards for the first time are coming to the realization that their facial hair is a tangle of waves and curls. But Matt Vilanova discovered how unmanageable his beard can be years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Bruenig and Damon Winter
title: ‘Pray for Your Poor Uncle,’ a Predatory Priest Told His Victims
description: As former Cardinal Theodore McCarrick became a powerful figure in the church, several boys from one family say he targeted them.
content: Rain fell in New York City four days before Christmas of 2018. Francis M. had planned to be in the city that day for business, but he had dutifully put aside time when asked to answer questions at the Archdiocese of New York offices about his experiences with “Uncle Ted” — former Cardinal Theodore McCarrick.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard C. Paddock and Saw Nang
title: Myanmar Plan to Breed Protected Species in Captivity Draws Criticism
description: Myanmar’s conservation ministry is considering captive breeding of as many as 175 threatened species, including tigers, Irrawaddy dolphins and rare birds that exist only in the wild.
content: BANGKOK — Myanmar will soon adopt rules that would permit captive breeding of about 175 threatened species, including tigers, pangolins and Irrawaddy dolphins, despite fears that such ventures could encourage poaching of wild animals and spawn new diseases that jump to humans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Powell
title: How a Famous Harvard Professor Became a Target Over His Tweets
description: The outcry over free speech and race takes aim at Steven Pinker, the best-selling author and well-known scholar.
content: Steven Pinker occupies a role that is rare in American life: the celebrity intellectual. The Harvard professor pops up on outlets from PBS to the Joe Rogan podcast, translating dense subjects into accessible ideas with enthusiasm. Bill Gates called his most recent book “my new favorite book of all time.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Croley
title: The Golf Party in This Ohio Town Has It All, Except Fans
description: The Memorial Tournament, a hallmark of central Ohio summers, had planned to host up to 8,000 fans daily until the PGA Tour reversed course.
content: DUBLIN, Ohio — In a typical year, the Bogey Inn would be preparing to party this week. While PGA Tour golfers ply their trade at nearby Muirfield Village Golf Club, site of the Memorial Tournament, the sports bar would welcome an overflow crowd of fans to enjoy a live band on its expansive patio outfitted with a disco ball.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Parul Sehgal
title: ‘Eat the Buddha’ Reports From the ‘World Capital of Self-Immolations’
description: Barbara Demick’s new book covers an awe-inspiring breadth of history — from the heyday of the Tibetan empire to the present-day Tibetan effort at cultural and spiritual survival.
content: In “The Unwomanly Face of War,” an oral history of World War II, the Nobel Prize-winning writer Svetlana Alexievich recounts a strange little story. A woman leaps into dark water to rescue a drowning man. At the shore, however, she realizes it is not a man she has hauled from the water but a gigantic sturgeon. The sturgeon dies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Small
title: How Artists Are Trying to Solve the World’s Problems
description: A cohort of 30 artists have received funding to find creative solutions to 21st-century problems like surveillance, digital inequality and inherited trauma.
content: Janine Soleil’s passing was sudden and shocking. She died a week after her 75th birthday in May, which was spent in hospice care after contracting the novel coronavirus. And once she was gone, her son, the artist Dylan Gauthier, found her digital imprint everywhere: on the dating websites where she found love, on the insurance company listings for her old therapy practice and across the hundreds of other websites she had tacitly agreed to share personal data with.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman and Katie Glueck
title: With Dueling Environmental Events, Trump and Biden Define the Race
description: Over two days, President Trump and Joseph R. Biden Jr. laid out wildly divergent views on environmental regulations and climate change, helping to define the stakes of the presidential race.
content: President Trump traveled on Wednesday to the new political battleground of Georgia to blast away at one of the nation’s cornerstone conservation laws, vowing to speed construction projects by limiting legally mandated environmental reviews of highways, pipelines and power plants.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gretchen Reynolds
title: How Exercise May Bolster the Brain
description: Exercise prompts the liver to pump out a little-known protein that appears to rejuvenate the brain, a new study found.
content: Exercise may help change exercisers’ brains in surprising ways, according to a new study of physical activity and brain health. The study, which included both mice and people, found that exercise prompts the liver to pump out a little-known protein, and that chemically upping the levels of that protein in out-of-shape, elderly animals rejuvenates their brains and memories. The findings raise provocative questions about whether the brain benefits of exercise might someday be available in a capsule or syringe form — essentially “exercise in a pill.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Drape
title: Bob Baffert Suspended 15 Days for Drug Positives
description: Two top horses, including an Arkansas Derby winner, were found to have a numbing agent in their systems.
content: The Arkansas Racing Commission suspended the Hall of Fame trainer Bob Baffert for 15 days on Wednesday and vacated the victories of two of his horses after they tested positive for a banned substance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Bruni
title: God Did Not Commute Roger Stone’s Sentence
description: Trump’s enablers recast rationalizations as righteousness.
content: This article is part of Frank Bruni’s free newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it every Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elaina Plott and Jeremy W. Peters
title: In Alabama, Can Doug Jones Fend Off Tommy Tuberville and Trump?
description: Mr. Tuberville, the Republicans’ new Senate nominee, will most likely repeat the same pro-Trump strategy he used to beat Jeff Sessions in the primary.
content: MOBILE, Ala. — On Tuesday evening, addressing supporters and the news media after his runaway victory in the Alabama Senate Republican primary, Tommy Tuberville wasted no time in pivoting toward his general-election opponent this fall, Senator Doug Jones. In Mr. Jones’s Alabama, he said, “You don’t work for the United States of America — you spend your first three years trying to impeach the best president we’ve ever had. And he voted to impeach him!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe and Lara Takenaga
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: The latest on vaccines.
content: During the trial of a vaccine, the final test is also its biggest: Phase 3. That’s when the vaccine is given to tens of thousands of people, along with a placebo group, to determine its safety and effectiveness. It’s the final step before a vaccine is approved and distributed to the public.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Republicans Won’t Do Much Convening in Florida, Colbert Thinks
description: “The only way it would be more infectious is if the dinner was an all-you-can-bob lasagna buffet,” Stephen Colbert said of the party’s upcoming convention in Jacksonville.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. We’re all stuck at home at the moment, so here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Lee Myers
title: China Vows to Retaliate After Trump Signs Hong Kong Sanctions Bill
description: Beijing accused the United States of “gross interference in Hong Kong affairs” and promised a response.
content: China on Wednesday sharply criticized President Trump’s moves to strip Hong Kong of its preferential trading status with the United States and clear the way for new sanctions on officials and companies there, vowing to retaliate with punitive measures of its own.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Mann
title: Comet NEOWISE: How to See It in Night Skies
description: Enjoy it while you can. The frozen ball of ice won’t return to the inner solar system for 6,800 years.
content: Eager sky watchers are turning to the heavens as Comet NEOWISE, one of the brightest comets in a generation, starts climbing ever higher among the evening stars.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Bari Weiss: A Fiery Parting Shot at The Times
description: Readers react to the resignation of a Times opinion editor and writer. Also: Tests for athletes; small-town journalism.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farhad Manjoo
title: Please Don’t Call Them Heroes
description: Parents and teachers need a real plan to reopen schools safely.
content: In America, you should always get a little suspicious when politicians suddenly start calling you a hero. It’s a well-worn trick; they’re buttering you up before sacrificing you to the gods of unconstrained capitalism and governmental neglect.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Roth
title: Scientists Accidentally Bred the Fish Version of a Liger
description: American paddlefish and Russian sturgeon were not supposed to be able to create hybrid offspring. Surprise!
content: At first glance, American paddlefish and Russian sturgeon seem about as different as two fish can be.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Send You to the Moon
description: Lee Higbie makes his New York Times Crossword debut, ably assisted by Jeff Chen.
content: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — Boom! Stay far back. Lee Higbie and Jeff Chen made a puzzle together, and they have apparently blown their tops.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: The Fed’s top regulator warns that global markets could turn messy.
description: Randal Quarles, the Federal Reserve’s top bank regulator and chair of the global Financial Stability Board, warned that markets could gyrate again and that it was possible investors were setting the stage for a sharp drop in asset prices.
content: Randal Quarles, the Federal Reserve’s top bank regulator and chair of the global Financial Stability Board, warned that markets could gyrate again and that it was possible investors were setting the stage for a sharp drop in asset prices.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hilary Sheinbaum
title: Turn Your Relationship Into a Work of Art
description: For some couples who postponed their engagement shoots because of the coronavirus, artists have stepped in to create custom illustrations and portraits.
content: As the coronavirus pandemic upended wedding plans and industry jobs, many couples rescheduled their engagement photo shoots in order to adhere to social distancing guidelines. Others hired illustrators to commemorate their upcoming nuptials, ceremonies and other relationship milestones. Here are a few creative examples from artists.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: The Guardian, seeing ‘unsustainable’ losses, will cut 180 jobs.
description: The British newspaper The Guardian said on Wednesday it would cut 12 percent of its work force, about 180 jobs, as it faces a shortfall of 25 million pounds ($31.5 million) caused by the economic impact of the pandemic.
content: The British newspaper The Guardian said on Wednesday it would cut 12 percent of its work force, about 180 jobs, as it faces a shortfall of 25 million pounds ($31.5 million) caused by the economic impact of the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manny Fernandez and Sarah Mervosh
title: Oklahoma Governor Tests Positive for Coronavirus
description: Gov. Kevin Stitt said he was “pretty shocked” to become the first governor known to have contracted the virus. Oklahoma has averaged more than 640 new cases per day over the past week.
content: Gov. Kevin Stitt of Oklahoma announced on Wednesday that he tested positive for the coronavirus, becoming the first governor in the United States known to have been infected during the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Bergner
title: ‘White Fragility’ Is Everywhere. But Does Antiracism Training Work?
description: Robin DiAngelo’s best seller is giving white Americans a new way to talk about race. Do those conversations actually serve the cause of equality?
content: To hear more audio stories from publishers like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan
title: Why You May Not Be Able to Get a Coronavirus Test in California
description: Wednesday: The state released new guidelines for testing that target people who have symptoms or may be part of outbreaks.
content: Good morning.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Welcome to the Happiest Place on Earth. Covid Testing Nightly.
description: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, July 15, 2020.
content: “This is going to be a very unique opportunity to observe the human condition.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: These Creamy Tomatoes Are the Ideal Lunch for One
description: You won’t want to share this deeply savory dish, and you don’t have to.
content: One of the joys of working from home is being able to make myself something for lunch that no one else in my family even remotely likes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Will Heinrich
title: Five Art Accounts to Follow on Instagram Now
description: Our critic looks at street photography that gives you a taste of global life during the lockdown, from Iran, the Democratic Republic of Congo, Hong Kong, South Korea and Ethiopia.
content: When things are tough at home, I sometimes search Instagram for street photographers abroad. It’s not that I’m looking for happy scenes, necessarily. It’s just reassuring to be reminded that the world is so much larger than our national news cycle. (Scrolling through digital feeds is also the safest way to travel these days, not to mention the most eco-friendly.) These are the five accounts that I’ve been turning to lately for quick little doses of our common humanity; other New York Times critics will be posting their own favorites regularly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: Just Collect Less Data, Period.
description: Every company wants the biggest data stockpile possible. We need unilateral data disarmament.
content: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: ‘Sole Source’ Contract for Covid-19 Database Draws Scrutiny From Democrats
description: But two top federal health officials defended the decision, saying that the new database was necessary to expedite and streamline data.
content: WASHINGTON — A $10.2 million “sole source” contract to run a centralized Covid-19 database for the Trump administration drew sharp criticism on Wednesday from congressional Democrats, who demanded that the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention be reinstated as the primary repository of coronavirus data.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Guy Trebay
title: For Paris Men’s Wear, the Next Stop Is California
description: Men’s wear shows in Europe this lockdown season may be virtual, but the dominant California vibe is very real.
content: We have seen the future of European fashion, and it is California.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: July 15, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, July 15, 2020.
content: An article on Saturday about the reluctance of public health experts to speak about the dangers of attending protests during a pandemic when the protests are against racism misstated the difference in life expectancy between Black Americans and white Americans. It is a difference of three and a half years, not two years.
source.name: The New York Times

title: One Meat Plant, One Thousand Infections: Revisiting Achut Deng
description: After surviving civil war in Sudan, one of America’s most vulnerable workers faced the coronavirus. How has she been doing since?
content: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Leland
title: Rev. Vickey Gibbs, Activist in a Progressive Church, Dies at 57
description: Ms. Gibbs used her pulpit in Houston to treat broken parishioners in a broken social world. She died of the coronavirus.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer
title: The Virus Is Stealing the Show, but Trump Is Sticking With Reruns
description: President Trump’s political strategy worked in 2016. Now he’s in charge and Americans aren’t happy.
content: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics. I’m Lisa Lerer, your host.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: Statue of Black Protester Is Raised in Place of Bristol Slave Trader
description: The image of Jen Reid, fist clenched atop the plinth in the English city where Edward Colston once stood, became a symbol of protest online. Now, it’s there in resin and steel.
content: LONDON — Jen Reid had never marched in a Black Lives Matter protest before she took to the streets of Bristol, England, on June 7. By the end of that angry day, she had clambered up to stand in the place of a 17th-century slave trader, whose bronze statue had been pulled down and dumped in the city’s harbor.
source.name: The New York Times

title: As U.S. Coronavirus Cases Hit 3.5 Million, Officials Scramble to Add Restrictions
description: More U.S. school districts have joined the move toward online learning for their reopening plans. China’s economy, the world’s second-largest, expanded in the second quarter.
content: The United States on Wednesday reported more than 67,300 new infections across the country, according to a New York Times database. It was the nation’s second-highest single-day total and roughly 1,000 cases shy of the record set last week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Tyra Banks Is Tapped as New ‘Dancing With the Stars’ Host
description: The former supermodel and businesswoman will fill the role Tom Bergeron occupied for the last 15 years.
content: A day after Tom Bergeron, the longtime “Dancing With the Stars” host, announced on Twitter that ABC had not invited him to return for the show’s 29th season, the network revealed his replacement: Tyra Banks, the former supermodel and businesswoman.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheera Frenkel, Nathaniel Popper, Kate Conger and David E. Sanger
title: A Brazen Online Attack Targets V.I.P. Twitter Users in a Bitcoin Scam
description: In a major show of force, hackers breached some of the site’s most prominent accounts, a Who’s Who of Americans in politics, entertainment and tech.
content: It was about 4 in the afternoon on Wednesday on the East Coast when chaos struck online. Dozens of the biggest names in America — including Joseph R. Biden Jr., Barack Obama, Kanye West, Bill Gates and Elon Musk — posted similar messages on Twitter: Send Bitcoin and the famous people would send back double your money.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elaina Plott
title: For Sessions, No Amount of Campaigning Could Overcome Trump in Alabama
description: He beat back tears. He said he let his family down. He declared of politics, “This chapter of my life is closed.” But he would not criticize his former boss, and even said President Trump could win in November.
content: MOBILE, Ala. — Jeff Sessions spent his final days on the campaign trail reiterating his support for President Trump’s agenda, reminding voters of his efforts to curb illegal immigration while attorney general and emphasizing how, as a senator, he had endorsed Mr. Trump’s presidential campaign at a time when few others in Washington would.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The ‘Moment of Truth’
description: Big banks say that it could get worse before it gets better.
content: A reminder to sign up for our DealBook Debrief call about “Trump’s Covid calculus” with The Times’s White House correspondent Maggie Haberman. It’s on July 16 at 11 a.m. Eastern and you can R.S.V.P. here. (Want this in your inbox each day? Sign up here.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Will Wright
title: Kansas Congressman Is Charged With Voter Fraud
description: Three felony charges were filed against Steve Watkins, a Republican, shortly before he appeared in a televised debate ahead of the state’s primary election.
content: Representative Steve Watkins, Republican of Kansas, was charged with three felonies related to voter fraud on Tuesday, shortly before a televised debate in which he dismissed the accusations involving a municipal election as a political move.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: The West Village: A Pause, and a Reset, for a Coveted Area
description: The neighborhood’s low-key, small-scale charms are gradually returning following the lockdown, although residential sales and prices are way down.
content: Store owners have barricaded their shops. West Fourth Street is missing its brunch-hour crowds. And shouting about masks occasionally erupts in packed Hudson River Park.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher F. Schuetze
title: ‘Forest Rambo’ Eludes German Police 3 Days Into Sprawling Hunt
description: A squatter armed with bow and arrow, spear and gun overpowered four officers and fled into the Black Forest on Sunday. Despite a huge search effort, he is still at large.
content: BERLIN — The call to the German police on Sunday seemed a bit odd but routine enough. A man armed with a bow and arrow had been squatting illegally in a small shed outside the village of Oppenau in the foothills of the Black Forest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: ViacomCBS Fires Nick Cannon, Citing Anti-Semitic Podcast Remarks
description: The network said that Mr. Cannon had promoted “hateful speech” during a recent episode of “Cannon’s Class,” his YouTube podcast.
content: The television star Nick Cannon was fired by ViacomCBS on Tuesday for making anti-Semitic remarks during a recent podcast in which he discussed conspiracy theories about Jewish people and praised a minister notorious for anti-Jewish comments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Mozur and Edward Wong
title: U.S. Weighs Sweeping Travel Ban on Chinese Communist Party Members
description: The presidential order under consideration would be based on the same statute in the Immigration and Nationality Act used in a 2017 travel ban on several predominantly Muslim countries.
content: The Trump administration is considering a sweeping ban on travel to the United States by members of the Chinese Communist Party and their families, according to people familiar with the proposal, a move that would almost certainly prompt retaliation against Americans seeking to enter or remain in China and exacerbate tensions between the two nations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Campbell Robertson
title: What Black Lives Matter Has Revealed About Small-Town America
description: A multiracial future has appeared, along with unprecedented conversations about race.
content: CHAMBERSBURG, Pa. — Nikki Wilkerson was used to thinking of herself as the “small brown girl” growing up in rural Pennsylvania.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes and Nicole Sperling
title: Hollywood Stays Away From Facebook Ad Boycott
description: The entertainment business is a big advertiser but has been noticeably silent as other industries protest the social network’s handling of hate speech.
content: LOS ANGELES — More than 1,000 companies have halted their Facebook advertising over the past month as part of a protest over the social network’s handling of hate speech, with most major industries represented in the boycott.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi
title: In Rare Surge of Online Unity, Iranians Call for Halt to Executions
description: Actors, scholars, star athletes and millions of others called for three young protesters’ lives to be spared. “I’m next, you’re next, we’re next,” one meme read.
content: Iranians from all walks of life — teachers, doctors, designers, cooks, actors, directors, artists, homemakers, bloggers — have taken to social media with a message for the government: Stop the executions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: Trump Weakens Major Conservation Law to Speed Construction Permits
description: President Trump has used a regulatory reinterpretation to limit one of the country's bedrock environmental laws and speed permitting of infrastructure projects.
content: WASHINGTON — President Trump on Wednesday unilaterally weakened one of the nation’s bedrock conservation laws, the National Environmental Policy Act, limiting public review of federal infrastructure projects to speed up the permitting of freeways, power plants and pipelines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Phillips
title: How Do You Translate a Comic Book Into Audio? Ask Neil Gaiman
description: In a new audio production, James McAvoy, Michael Sheen and a full cast give voice to “The Sandman.”
content: This is what dreaming sounds like.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Steinhauer
title: Victory Gardens Were More About Solidarity Than Survival
description: During World War II, millions of Americans grew their own vegetables, but the movement was driven much more by government and corporate messaging than by the threat of starvation.
content: In the latest article from “Beyond the World War II We Know,” a series from The Times that documents lesser-known stories from World War II, we recount the history of victory gardens and some of the misconceptions of how they emerged after the United States joined the conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Winnie Hu and Nate Schweber
title: New York City Has 2,300 Parks. But Poor Neighborhoods Lose Out.
description: Governors Island and other large parks are trying to attract more underserved visitors, who need outdoor space more than ever during the pandemic.
content: Governors Island, a 172-acre oasis in the middle of New York Harbor, has become one of New York’s City’s most popular summer playgrounds with hammocks, biking and spectacular water views.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Corkery
title: Walmart, Nation’s Largest Retailer, Will Require Customers to Wear Masks
description: The new rule, which goes into effect on Monday, is a strong statement about wearing masks in public spaces at a time when the issue has become politicized.
content: In perhaps the strongest statement yet by a major American company about the importance of masks, Walmart said it would require that all of its customers wear face coverings starting next week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: The Wave of Gun Violence in N.Y.C.
description: Fifty-three people were shot from Friday through Monday. Officials have suggested  reasons, but it’s difficult to pinpoint one root cause.
content: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: ‘They Go to Mommy First’
description: How the pandemic is disproportionately disrupting mothers’ careers.
content: Maggie Levine was on maternity leave from her job as a children’s librarian in Boston for the first few months of the pandemic, but she started working again in the middle of May. She and her husband, James Maher, an engineer, had no outside child care between mid-May and early July, while she was working from home and he was working part time from home and part time from the office. They were both caring for their baby, who is now 9 months old.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Holly Rosenkrantz
title: Coronavirus Tests Can Be Scary For Kids. Here’s How to Make Them Easier.
description: A nasal swab is invasive and uncomfortable for anyone. For kids, knowing what to expect can help ease the anxiety.
content: Cynthia Jaeger was packing up the family minivan for the two-hour trip from her house in Richmond, Va., to Washington, D.C., when her 8-year-old daughter began having an anxiety attack. Zoey, Jaeger’s middle child, has a rare neurological condition, and she needed to go to Children’s National Hospital for chemotherapy and intensive cognitive testing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ceylan Yeginsu
title: For U.K.’s Minority Women, Economic Toll of Lockdown Lingers
description: Black and other ethnic minority groups have long faced economic and racial inequality in Britain. As workers return, many are saddled with debt and working longer hours for less pay.
content: LONDON — Within 10 days of the British government’s lockdown announcement in late March, one woman lost all nine of her cleaning jobs. Another was laid off from a laundromat after she requested a mask, and a live-in nanny was fired for using public transport on her day off.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Weiser
title: Former Manhattan Federal Prosecutor Fired by Trump to Teach at Stanford
description: Geoffrey S. Berman will be a visiting professor of law at Stanford Law School.
content: Geoffrey S. Berman, the former U.S. attorney for the Southern District of New York who was abruptly fired last month by President Trump, will be a visiting professor at Stanford Law School for the fall 2020 term, the school said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Paton
title: Burberry is set to cut hundreds of jobs in its latest cost-saving drive.
description: Sales plummeted in the first quarter as countries closed shops and offices and limited travel to control the spread of Covid-19
content: The British luxury retailer Burberry plans to cut up to 500 jobs worldwide as it continues to grapple with the impact of the coronavirus on its business.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi
title: Boeing’s 737 Max Will Return to a Devastated Aviation Industry
description: Airlines have canceled orders for hundreds of the troubled jet because of its safety problems and the pandemic, but others are still eager to buy them.
content: The first half of the year was not kind to the 737 Max. Boeing froze production of its beleaguered plane from January through much of May as customers canceled hundreds of orders, and deals for hundreds more were put at risk by delays in the plane’s return to the skies and the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.J. Goldmann
title: Wagner in the Parking Lot as Opera Returns to Germany
description: Three productions under unusual constraints show how the art form is gradually re-emerging in the pandemic.
content: BERLIN — The Rhinemaidens lament their lost gold on asphalt. Tristan savors doomed love in a stately 17th-century garden. A motley crew of playboys and deposed royalty are set adrift in an industrial harbor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Anderson
title: When the President Shows You an Old Man Shouting ‘White Power’
description: There are all sorts of interesting things you might learn from the video Donald Trump retweeted. The president, it would seem, noticed none of them.
content: To hear more audio stories from publishers like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Molly Neptune Parker, Basket Maker and Tribal Elder, Dies at 81
description: Ms. Parker was the matriarch of four generations of basket makers and one of the first female lieutenant governors of the Passamaquoddy Tribe.
content: There were years when Molly Neptune Parker would work the night shift at a wool factory, after having put in a full day making baskets, and still be home in time to serve her children breakfast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Grace Edquist
title: Hermès Introduces Seasonless Staples for the Long Haul
description: Breaking with the standard fashion calendar, the brand has created a capsule collection inspired by its archives.
content: As the artistic director of women’s ready-to-wear at Hermès, Nadège Vanhée-Cybulski is deeply familiar with the fashion calendar, its shows and seasons coming at a quick but constant pace. Last spring, though, she was staring down the maternity leave she would soon take following the birth of her first child — an event that can’t help but remake one’s relationship with time — and found herself wanting to take advantage of the remaining weeks before she went. “We decided to do this capsule collection we’d always talked about,” she says of her team, which works out of the brand’s atelier in Pantin, just north of Paris. “Something special created out of season, when we can really explore.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Graham Bowley
title: Complaint Faults Museum Director for Hanging His In-Law’s El Greco
description: A whistle-blower accusation argues that conflict-of-interest rules to prevent self-dealing have been skirted at the Detroit Institute of Arts.
content: It was a chance to borrow a rarely seen El Greco for a museum that had only a single painting by the old master.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Serena Puang
title: Living With Aphantasia, the Inability to Make Mental Images
description: When the mind’s eye cannot see, counting sheep or navigating streets with a “mental map” can be impossible.
content: When I was in elementary school, I occasionally had trouble falling asleep, and people would tell me to count sheep. I had seen the activity graphically depicted in cartoons, but when I tried it, I never saw anything — just black. I’ve been counting silently into the darkness for years.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Music as a ‘Means to an End’
description: In a New York Times “Live at Home” event, the recording artists Meshell Ndegeocello, Brandi Carlile and Hayley Kiyoko explored the role of activism in their work.
content: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lou Stoppard
title: The Phantom Handbag
description: No one needed a bag when we were stuck in lockdown. Will we ever embrace the accessory again?
content: I feel it sometimes, like a phantom limb, banging against my side as I move around the house. I sense it nestled in the crook of my arm as I wander from room to room. It was the one-time receptacle of all I held immediately important: purse, receipts, identification, charger, books, tissues (fresh and used), flask, tampons, a card for that delicious but inexpensive Italian restaurant from that onetime a few months back.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Who Made My Puzzle?
description: This month’s constructor spotlight shines on Kevin Christian.
content: Burlingame, Calif., which is about 15 miles south of San Francisco.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Libbey
title: Metropolitan Museum of Art to Reopen Five Days a Week in August
description: Three new exhibitions will be on display when the museum’s Fifth Avenue location begins welcoming visitors again on Aug. 29.
content: The Metropolitan Museum of Art announced on Wednesday that its landmark location on Fifth Avenue will welcome visitors five days a week, Thursday through Monday, when it reopens to the public on Aug. 29.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Iliana Magra
title: Homesick Student Cycles From Scotland to Greece During the Pandemic
description: It took the 20-year-old Kleon Papadimitriou 48 days to travel from Aberdeen to Athens, riding more than 2,000 miles as the coronavirus shut down other modes of transport.
content: LONDON — Nearly a month into the coronavirus lockdown, Kleon Papadimitriou, a Greek student in Aberdeen, Scotland, was feeling homesick.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold, William K. Rashbaum and Daniel E. Slotnik
title: Dismemberment Killing of Tech C.E.O. ‘Looks Like Professional Job’
description: Fahim Saleh, 33, was followed into his luxury Manhattan condo by a man dressed all in black, the official said.
content: The killer, dressed entirely in black and wearing a black mask, followed the young technology entrepreneur from the elevator of his luxury condo building into his apartment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley and Ben Casselman
title: A Resurgence of the Virus, and Lockdowns, Threatens Economic Recovery
description: Hopes for a rebound are endangered by prolonged closures of schools, renewed state restrictions on business and fears of a difficult autumn and winter.
content: WASHINGTON — The United States economy is headed for a tumultuous autumn, with the threat of closed schools, renewed government lockdowns, empty stadiums and an uncertain amount of federal support for businesses and unemployed workers all clouding hopes for a rapid rebound from recession.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elaine Glusac
title: New Twists on Home-Sharing: 4 Airbnb Alternatives
description: They are small, ambitious and target savvy travelers. But their main goal is to improve the home-sharing experience for hosts and renters alike.
content: In 2017, Victoria O’Connell rented her London apartment via a home-sharing site to a man who looted and wrecked the place during a party that drew the police. He disappeared, but left her a review on the platform, saying, “Great host.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabe Cohn
title: What’s on TV Wednesday: ‘First Cow’ and ‘The Line’
description: The latest film from Kelly Reichardt is available online. And the Public Theater is streaming a virtual play about the pandemic.
content: FIRST COW (2020) Buy on Amazon, Google Play, iTunes, Vudu and YouTube. At a settlement in the Oregon Territory in the mid-19th century, two men set up shop on a patch of ground. Their product, fried dough with modest garnish, sells out almost instantly. The secret ingredient? Stolen milk. The buddies who cook up that clever racket are at the heart of this latest western from Kelly Reichardt. When “First Cow” introduces Cookie (John Magaro) and King-Lu (Orion Lee), they’re strangers: Cookie is working as a cook and forager for a group of trappers; King-Lu is on the run. The friendship they develop together — and their covert dairy operation — is explored against a forested frontier backdrop. A.O. Scott called the film “deceptively simple and wondrously subtle” in his review for The New York Times. “A parable of economics and politics, with shrewd insights into the workings of supply and demand, scarcity and scale and other puzzles of the marketplace, the movie is also keenly attuned to details of history, both human and natural,” he wrote.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reggie Ugwu
title: How ‘I May Destroy You’ Got Its Stunning Soundtrack
description: The show’s 27-year-old music supervisor, Ciara Elwis, talks about matching Michaela Coel’s singular vision with songs by Nicki Minaj, Daft Punk and more.
content: In the world of “I May Destroy You,” the critically hailed HBO/BBC series written, co-directed by and starring Michaela Coel, few things are ever static. The show, like its central characters — young, exuberantly liberated but inherently vulnerable Black Britons navigating sex, power and friendship in a very recent London — is held together by the cumulative force of its apparent contradictions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Schwartz
title: That Siberian Heat Wave? Yes, Climate Change Was a Big Factor
description: An analysis of recent record temperatures found that climate change made this year’s long hot spell 600 times more likely.
content: This year’s startling heat across much of Siberia would have been all but impossible without human influence on climate change, researchers have concluded.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Goldstein and Eliza Shapiro
title: Most Big School Districts Aren’t Ready to Reopen. Here’s Why.
description: All but two of the nation’s 10 largest districts exceed a key public health threshold, according to a New York Times analysis.
content: As education leaders decide whether to reopen classrooms in the fall amid a raging pandemic, many are looking to a standard generally agreed upon among epidemiologists: To control community spread of the coronavirus, the average daily infection rate among those who are tested should not exceed 5 percent.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 2020 Election Updates: Polls Suggest Trump Is Losing His Edge on the Economy
description: Last month, a majority of voters said they trusted President Trump over Mr. Biden to handle the economy, but a new poll shows the opposite. Mr. Trump visited Georgia as the G.O.P. turned to Senate battles there.
content: This briefing has now ended. Follow all of our election coverage here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Pogrebin
title: Smithsonian Chief Says He Will Look Into Staff Complaint of Racism
description: Lonnie G. Bunch III, the Smithsonian’s secretary, responded to a letter of “outrage” from former staff members at the National Museum of African Art.
content: Lonnie G. Bunch III, who last year became the first Black secretary of the Smithsonian Institution, said in an interview Wednesday that is he reviewing complaints in a letter sent by former employees and board members of its National Museum of African Art that described it as a bad place for Black employees.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Hale
title: Can’t Match Netflix? At Least You Can Buy Some British Shows
description: Like HBO Max, Peacock fills out its initial roster of originals with some English-speaking imports.
content: When you want to start a streaming service and your most established competitor has for years been spending billions of dollars making and acquiring exclusive series, what do you do?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Felipe Neto
title: Trump Isn’t the Worst Pandemic President
description: Just ask Brazilians.
content: Who’s the world’s worst leader at handling the pandemic? Easy. Donald Trump. Right? Well, as terrible as Mr. Trump is, a Brazilian YouTube star, Felipe Neto, argues it’s actually his president, Jair Bolsonaro.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins
title: Who Can Make Trump Miserable This Fall?
description: Goodbye, Jeff Sessions, hello … Heir Archy.
content: I hope by now you’ve managed to come to grips with the fact that we’re no longer going to have Jeff Sessions in our lives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: Sessions Falls in Alabama, and Gideon Rises in Maine
description: Alabama sides with Trump, and anti-G.O.P. energy builds in Maine: This is your morning tip sheet.
content: Jeff Sessions goes down, Trump retreats from a hard-line position on international student visas, and Biden announces an ambitious climate plan — just don’t call it a Green New Deal. It’s Wednesday, and this is your politics tip sheet. Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Linda Qiu
title: Trump’s Falsehoods on Police Shootings, Biden, Coronavirus and China
description: Speaking in the Rose Garden and in an earlier television interview, the president made incorrect, misleading and exaggerated statements on a wide variety of topics.
content: In a rambling, campaign-style appearance in the Rose Garden at the White House and in an interview with CBS News on Tuesday, President Trump ranged across many topics, sprinkling questionable assertions throughout his remarks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sameer Yasir
title: Monsoon Rains Pummel South Asia, Displacing Millions
description: Flooding in Bangladesh, Bhutan, India, Myanmar and Nepal has killed scores of people, destroyed homes and structures, drowned entire villages, and forced many to crouch on rooftops hoping for rescue.
content: When heavy floods started inundating her riverside home last week in the village of Madarganj, northern Bangladesh, Habiba Begum chose to stay put with her family instead of moving to shelter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Renard
title: You May Not Know These 15 Songs. But You’ve Heard Them.
description: Artists like Edwin Birdsong and Ballin’ Jack aren’t household names, but their music is instantly recognizable as the samples behind hit pop songs.
content: “Sampling Is (a) Creative or (b) Theft,” read a New York Times headline in 1997, summarizing a debate that has raged ever since songs started incorporating parts of other songs. The truth? It’s a little of both, and that’s what’s so fun about it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Satariano
title: Apple Scores Legal Victory Against $14.9 Billion E.U. Tax Demand
description: The decision is a setback for European efforts to clamp down on what the authorities there believe is anticompetitive behavior.
content: LONDON — Apple won a major legal victory on Wednesday against European antitrust regulators as a European court overruled a 2016 decision that ordered the company to pay $14.9 billion in unpaid taxes to Ireland.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William K. Rashbaum and Benjamin Weiser
title: Trump Raises New Objections to Subpoena Seeking His Tax Returns
description: The effort came less than a week after the U.S. Supreme Court cleared the way for the Manhattan district attorney to demand the records.
content: Days after the U.S. Supreme Court delivered a defeat to President Trump, clearing the way for the Manhattan district attorney to seek his tax returns, his lawyers on Wednesday renewed their efforts to block or at least narrow access to the records.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marcelle Sussman Fischler
title: House Hunting in Israel: A Modern Stone Farmhouse on 1.5 Acres
description: As the government takes measures to cool rising prices, the nation’s housing market is beginning to emerge from its pandemic paralysis.
content: This Israeli version of a Mediterranean country home faces northwest toward the biblical Mount Tabor in the Lower Galilee region east of Haifa, Israel’s third-largest city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Donald G. McNeil Jr
title: Your Ancestors Knew Death in Ways You Never Will
description: Some say we’re doomed. But science and public spending have saved us from pandemics worse than this one.
content: Nearly 140,000 Americans have been lost to coronavirus, and many experts fear the deaths will only accelerate in the fall as cold weather forces us indoors. By year’s end, half as many Americans may have died as did in the four years of World War II.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum
title: New York Times Will Move Part of Hong Kong Office to Seoul
description: A sweeping national security law passed by China in June has unsettled news organizations and created uncertainty about the city’s prospects as a hub for journalism in Asia.
content: This article has been updated to include new details on The Times’s visa troubles in Hong Kong as well as comments from the Chinese Foreign Ministry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Denise Grady
title: First Coronavirus Vaccine Tested in Humans Shows Early Promise
description: The vaccine, developed by government scientists and Moderna, a biotech company, appeared safe and provoked an immune response in 45 people in a study.
content: An experimental coronavirus vaccine made by the biotech company Moderna provoked a promising immune response against the virus and appeared safe in the first 45 people who received it, researchers reported on Tuesday in The New England Journal of Medicine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: ‘Just Let Those Kids Dance’: Finding a Way for the Show to Go On
description: For dance students, the annual recital is the biggest event of the year. Whether in parks or in parking lots, some studios are determined to make it happen in a pandemic year.
content: RANDALLSTOWN, Md. — On a sweltering Sunday afternoon in July, families sat in folding chairs arranged in socially distant clusters in the half-empty parking lot of a strip mall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gillian R. Brassil
title: Tuberville Advances: Will Alabama Send an Auburn Coach to the Senate?
description: Tommy Tuberville led Auburn to an undefeated season in 2004. Now that he’s running for a Senate seat, will Alabama fans forgive him?
content: Tommy Tuberville, who made his name as one of the most successful football coaches at Auburn, won in overtime and now faces an intrastate rival in Alabama.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Citing Educational Risks, Scientific Panel Urges That Schools Reopen
description: Younger children in particular are ill-served by remote learning, according to a report issued by the National Academies of Science, Engineering and Medicine.
content: Wading into the contentious debate over reopening schools, an influential committee of scientists and educators on Wednesday recommended that, wherever possible, younger children and those with special needs should attend school in person.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Somini Sengupta and Hiroko Tabuchi
title: ‘The City I Love’ and Climate Change: A Miami Story
description: Also this week, who cleans up when oil and gas companies fail?
content: Welcome to the Climate Fwd: newsletter. The New York Times climate team emails readers once a week with stories and insights about climate change. Sign up here to get it in your inbox.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi
title: Burning Ships in Iran Add to String of Dozens of Explosions and Fires
description: Iranian officials say that some of the explosions at factories and military facilities, and some forest fires, may have been sabotage but blamed weather and accidents for the others.
content: A large fire broke out at a shipyard in the southern Iranian port city of Bushehr on Wednesday, burning seven ships and sending plumes of black smoke billowing above the city skyline, according to videos and Iranian media reports.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsay Crouse
title: 10 Things I Hate About Taxes
description: Fielding the many invasive questions of my online tax prep service.
content: Lindsay, welcome back to your 15th year with our online tax prep service! We have just a few simple questions to help you get started.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Sanders, M.D
title: She Tested Negative for Lyme Disease. So What Was Wrong?
description: Her lethargy and joint pain suggested a tick-borne illness. Adding to the mystery, was a recent trip abroad a clue or a red herring?
content: The 50-year-old physician dropped into the leather chair in her psychiatrist’s Manhattan office. Her new normal, she announced to Dr. Deborah Cabaniss, was constant fatigue. Cabaniss noted that although her patient looked put together as usual, she could see the exhaustion in her eyes. “You don’t look like yourself,” the therapist agreed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elaina Plott and Jonathan Martin
title: Sessions Pays the Price for Incurring Trump’s Wrath, Losing Alabama Senate Race
description: In Maine, Sara Gideon prevailed over limited competition in the Democratic primary for Senate and will face Susan Collins in a race that has become the priciest Senate campaign in the state’s history.
content: MOBILE, Ala. — As a longtime senator from Alabama, Jeff Sessions did nothing less than legitimize Donald. J. Trump as a credible Republican candidate for president, endorsing him when no other big names did and championing him to conservative voters. As Mr. Trump’s star rose, Mr. Sessions’s rose, too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Sara Gideon Wins Nomination to Challenge Susan Collins in Maine
description: Ms. Gideon, backed by the Senate Democratic campaign arm and outside political groups, had long been the favorite to challenge Senator Collins, the sole remaining New England Republican in Congress.
content: WASHINGTON — Sara Gideon, the speaker of the Maine House of Representatives, on Tuesday formally became the Democratic nominee to challenge Senator Susan Collins of Maine, wielding a formidable war chest in a race that could determine whether Republicans retain control of the Senate in November.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Do When Most Days Feel Like Wednesdays
description: Seek diversion from what’s happening in your head and in our world, if just for a moment of recharge and reflection. It works.
content: Welcome. How are you? Wednesdays were a bear even before the pandemic came to town and made most days feel like Wednesdays. Now Wednesdays are like Wednesdays squared, like Nebraska on a cross-country drive, 456 miles from Omaha in the East all the way to the Wyoming line. They’re a long way from a weekend that is hardly a weekend for many, in both directions on the calendar.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times Opinion
title: How Will Your Life Change if Congress Cuts Your Jobless Benefits?
description: Our journalists want to hear your story.
content: On July 26, an unemployment insurance benefits program providing an extra $600 per week to more than 30 million jobless Americans will expire.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Ronny Jackson, Ex-White House Doctor, Wins Texas House Runoff
description: Dr. Jackson, a Republican who was backed by President Trump and based his campaign around their close relationship, effectively stamped his ticket to Congress in a deep-red district.
content: Dr. Ronny L. Jackson, the former White House physician with no political experience who ran a campaign based on his close relationship with President Trump, won a Republican runoff election for a House seat in Texas on Tuesday night, effectively stamping his ticket to Congress next year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Williamson and Sarah Mervosh
title: Western Outbreaks Threaten Tourist Season at National Parks
description: Americans crave outdoor recreation more than ever. But national parks — sometimes many miles from equipped hospitals — are grappling with how to safely stay open.
content: GRAND CANYON NATIONAL PARK, Ariz. — Glowing purple and scarlet in fading afternoon light, the geological marvel that is the Grand Canyon, the crown jewel of America’s national park system, draws more than six million global visitors in a normal year and fuels the economy of Arizona.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Flitter
title: Black Business Owners Had a Harder Time Getting Federal Aid, a Study Finds
description: A nonprofit sent Black and white “mystery shoppers” to branches of 17 banks, where they asked for loans under the Paycheck Protection Program. White customers got better treatment.
content: Black business owners are more likely to be hindered in seeking coronavirus financial aid than their white peers, a new study has found.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Arango, Matt Furber and Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: Footage of Police Body Cameras Offers Devastating Account of Floyd Killing
description: The footage was made available by appointment at a court in Minneapolis, and shows officers seemingly more concerned with controlling George Floyd’s body than saving his life.
content: MINNEAPOLIS — Almost from the moment George Floyd encountered the police on May 25, with a gun pointed at him, he appeared terrified and emotionally distraught, according to police camera footage that was newly made available for viewing Wednesday at a courthouse in downtown Minneapolis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: Your New Favorite Sandwich
description: The chef Brooks Headley’s crispy chicken-fried tofu sandwich is a riff on chicken-fried steak, and neither complicated nor difficult.
content: Good morning. The chef Brooks Headley is in the spotlight today, with his recipe for the crispy chicken-fried tofu sandwich (above) served at his Superiority Burger on the Lower East Side of Manhattan. It’s a bit of a project as most restaurant recipes tend to be, but it’s neither complicated nor difficult. If you start the process this afternoon, you’ll eat a sandwich of intense deliciousness for dinner and be thankful for having done so, against the backdrop of our troubled, reeling world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: After Attacks From Trump Aides, Fauci Says ‘Let’s Stop This Nonsense’ and Focus on Virus
description: The White House has insisted there is no concerted effort to attack the government’s leading expert on infectious diseases. But Dr. Fauci called the criticism against him “bizarre.”
content: WASHINGTON — After several days spent weathering attacks from White House officials, Dr. Anthony S. Fauci hit back on Wednesday, calling recent efforts to discredit him “bizarre” and a hindrance to the government’s ability to communicate information about the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: The White House Called a News Conference. Trump Turned It Into a Meandering Monologue.
description: The president spoke in the Rose Garden for 63 minutes. He spent only six of those minutes answering questions from reporters.
content: WASHINGTON — In theory, President Trump summoned television cameras to the heat-baked Rose Garden early Tuesday evening to announce new measures against China to punish it for its oppression of Hong Kong. But that did not last long.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Thursday Briefing
description: Huawei, Philippine police, Seoul investigation: Here’s what you need to know.
content: Secretary of State Mike Pompeo announced that the U.S. would impose visa restrictions for Huawei and other tech employees and their families.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross
title: Teenage Suspect Charged in Fatal Shooting of 8-Year-Old Girl in Atlanta
description: The death of Secoriea Turner has roiled Atlanta. A lawyer for the suspect said his client, who turned himself in, witnessed the shooting but did not open fire.
content: A teenager was charged on Wednesday in the fatal shooting of Secoriea Turner, an 8-year-old girl who died this month in Atlanta after an armed group stopped her family’s car and opened fire, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Risa Brooks
title: The Herculean Effort to Build an American Army
description: Paul Dickson’s “The Rise of the G.I. Army, 1940-1941” tells the remarkable story of how the United States created an effective military from scratch.
content: THE RISE OF THE G.I. ARMY, 1940-1941The Forgotten Story of How America Forged a Powerful Army Before Pearl HarborBy Paul Dickson
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: ‘Now I Am Become Death’: The Legacy of the First Nuclear Bomb Test
description: The 75th anniversary of what’s known as the Trinity explosion, the world’s first nuclear weapon test, comes as tensions over nuclear devices intensify.
content: It was 1 a.m. on July 16, 1945, when J. Robert Oppenheimer met with an Army lieutenant general, Leslie Groves, in the parched landscape of Jornada del Muerto — Dead Man’s Journey — a remote desert in New Mexico.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stacy Cowley
title: States Sue Education Dept. Over Relief for Cheated Students
description: The lawsuit, filed by the attorneys general for 22 states and the District of Columbia, says the department broke federal law and imposed standards that are impossible for defrauded students to meet.
content: Twenty-two states and the District of Columbia sued the Education Department on Wednesday, claiming it broke federal law in adopting new rules for a program meant to wipe out the student loan debt of borrowers whose schools defrauded them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Stein
title: Life Inside the N.B.A. Bubble
description: In this week’s newsletter, Marc Stein describes his first 48 hours in quarantine at Walt Disney World and discusses recent comments by the former player Stephen Jackson.
content: Want more basketball in your inbox? Sign up for Marc Stein’s weekly N.B.A. newsletter here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Caramanica
title: Country Music Struggles to Meet the Moment. Again.
description: The larger music industry has vowed to examine racism and bias. In Nashville, only the genre’s outsiders are dipping their toes in essential conversations.
content: Scornful and indignant, Eric Church — the most accessible of country music’s contemporary heretics — begins his new single, “Stick That in Your Country Song,” with an image of a decayed America:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin and Marcus Payadue
title: Anthony Fauci, Heat Wave, Hot Dogs: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Seth Schiesel
title: The Sims Is Bringing Its Inclusive Spirit to TV
description: In a new reality show based on the computer games, players compete for prize money. But the narrative of “The Sims Spark’d” emerges from how the series allows them to convey their own experiences.
content: Deep down, Rayvon Owen already knew he was gay when a classmate introduced him to the Sims back in 2003, when they were in sixth grade in Richmond, Va.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Our 2020-21 Student Contest Calendar
description: From art and editorials to personal narratives and podcasts, a list of the 10 contests and challenges for young people we’re running this school year.
content: Tens of thousands of students from around the world participate in our contests each year,  creating podcasts, writing editorials, telling stories, documenting their lives, and responding to the news.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cecilia Kang, Lara Jakes, Ana Swanson and David McCabe
title: TikTok Enlists Army of Lobbyists as Suspicions Over China Ties Grow
description: The viral social media app has beefed up its lobbying operation to counter several potential actions in Washington that could threaten the company’s future.
content: WASHINGTON — TikTok, the wildly popular social media app known for its viral dance and lip sync clips, has been embraced by millions of students, celebrities and young adults across the United States. But the company’s ties to China could cripple its existence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: A Different Cold War
description: And what else you need to know today.
content: The relationship between China and the United States continues to deteriorate, as The Times’s Steven Lee Myers and Paul Mozur explain. The two countries are clashing over Hong Kong, digital technology, trade, the South China Sea and more.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mara Altman
title: Who Helps Out in a Crisis?
description: Women and men are equally likely to step up in a time of crisis, but they tend to do so in different ways.
content: — Kathleen Tierney, a co-author of “Disasters, Collective Behavior, and Social Organization”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian X. Chen
title: You’re Doomscrolling Again. Here’s How to Snap Out of It.
description: In a pandemic that forces us to stay home, bingeing on doom-and-gloom news feels irresistible. These health experts offer ways to break the habit.
content: Your phone alarm goes off at 6 in the morning. You check some news sites and Facebook. It’s bad news after bad news. Coronavirus cases keep climbing, and so do deaths. Children can’t go back to school. Your favorite restaurant and barbershop are still closed. People are losing their jobs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Winkie
title: Meet the 19-Year-Old From Kazakhstan Who Remixed ‘Roses’ Into a Hit
description: Imanbek was working at his local train station when he stumbled onto a Saint Jhn song ripe for a dancey redo. The result boosted both artists to a new level.
content: Imanbek Zeikenov is 19 years old and lives with his parents in the small village of Aksu in Kazakhstan. He studied railway engineering at school, and until last December, held a day job at his local train station. But everything changed in the summer of 2019, when he discovered a song called “Roses” by the Guyanese-American rapper and singer Saint Jhn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: Obies Honor ‘A Strange Loop’ and ‘Heroes of the Fourth Turning’
description: The annual awards show for Off and Off Off Broadway theater was prerecorded and streamed after the coronavirus led to cancellation of a live ceremony.
content: “A Strange Loop,” Michael R. Jackson's meta-musical about race, sexuality and musical theater, and “Heroes of the Fourth Turning,” Will Arbery’s play about faith and politics in a corner of the conservative Catholic world, were the most-honored shows Tuesday night at the annual Obie Awards.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Calarco
title: What Is Betsy DeVos Thinking?
description: The education secretary is pushing schools to reopen without helping them to do so safely.
content: As the coronavirus continues to wreak havoc across the United States, some public K-12 schools may be able to reopen safely, but doing so will not be cheap. A recent report from the Council of Chief State School Officers estimated that public K-12 schools will need as much as $245 billion in additional funding to open with the recommended protocols in place from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Yet with local and state budgets strapped, many schools are likely to fall short unless they receive considerable federal support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noah Weiland
title: Chief Vaccine Scientist Will Not Be Forced to Disclose Pharmaceutical Stocks
description: Dr. Moncef Slaoui, the chief adviser for the Trump administration’s coronavirus vaccine program, can remain a government contractor, thus shielding him from disclosure rules.
content: WASHINGTON — The scientist leading the Trump administration’s coronavirus vaccine program will be allowed to remain a government contractor, a decision that permits him to avoid ethics disclosures required of federal employees and maintain his investments in pharmaceutical companies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacey Fortin and Allyson Waller
title: 87 Face Felony Charges After Protesting Breonna Taylor’s Death
description: The demonstrators were arrested at the home of Kentucky’s attorney general in Louisville, where they had gathered to demand charges against the officers who killed Ms. Taylor.
content: Dozens of protesters were charged with a felony on Tuesday after they gathered on property owned by Kentucky’s attorney general to demand charges against the police officers responsible for the shooting death of Breonna Taylor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: U.K.-Huawei, Europe Economy, China: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

title: Buying tech stocks is the ‘most crowded’ trade in history.
description: For the past 25 years, Bank of America has surveyed fund managers about how they are positioning their portfolios. When a consensus emerges, the bank’s pollsters say, investors generally profit by betting against it, according to today’s DealBook newsletter.
content: For the past 25 years, Bank of America has surveyed fund managers about how they are positioning their portfolios. When a consensus emerges, the bank’s pollsters say, investors generally profit by betting against it, according to today’s DealBook newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Lasky
title: $1.3 Million Homes in New York, Ohio and California
description: An artist’s studio and cottage in Greenport, a Tudor Revival house in Shaker Heights and a two-bedroom condo a block from the ocean in Santa Monica.
content: Once the community laundry facility for Greenport, a fishing village on the North Fork of Long Island, the property was later the studio of Rob Pruitt, an artist who sold it, in 2006, to Clay Weiner, a writer and director for television, film and advertising. Mr. Pruitt oversaw its most recent renovations into a live-work space.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Playwrights Horizons Details First Season Under New Leadership
description: Though no dates are set, Adam Greenfield plans to present four plays, all directed by women, at the Off Broadway theater.
content: In his first season at the helm of Playwrights Horizons, Adam Greenfield is sending a message: The organization may be staging fewer shows because of the pandemic — four in its 2021 season, down from the six that were slated for the 2019-2020 season — but it is committed to showcasing work by writers of color.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Phillips
title: A Plague on Your Houses: Reading Covid-19 Into Disease Onstage
description: Efforts like ‘The Oedipus Project’ are worthy, but in an attempt to draw contemporary parallels, they can misread drama and mislead about the present.
content: “The hateful plague spreads like a raging wildfire, devouring the city without mercy, emptying homes and filling the streets with moans and wailing and heaps of rotting bodies,” declares a priest in “The Oedipus Project,” Theater of War Productions’ recent reading of scenes from “Oedipus the King,” translated and directed by Bryan Doerries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brianna Holt
title: The Return of Jane Elliott
description: Before anti-racist reading lists and Instagram allyship, white people were presented with the “Blue Eyes, Brown Eyes” exercise. Its 86-year-old creator can’t believe she’s still being asked about it.
content: The day after the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was assassinated in 1968, the schoolteacher Jane Elliott scrapped her lesson plan — teaching her third graders the Sioux prayer about not judging another person until you have “walked a mile in his moccasins” — for an experiential learning exercise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Samin Nosrat
title: Gardening Made Me Happier. It Will Work for You Too.
description: Samin Nosrat turns to her vegetable plot for solace — and flavor. Her favorite is something many farmers throw away: fresh coriander seeds.
content: When I’m angry — which is often these days — I pull weeds. Getting my hands in the dirt untangles the knots that form in my stomach. With the first few weeds, I feel my exasperation with those who refuse to wear masks relent. It takes a little more digging and pulling to address the rage that builds up each day while I listen to friends and colleagues who have been mistreated by the food-media organizations that are now being exposed for systemic racial injustices.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allison McCann, Blacki Migliozzi, Andy Newman, Larry Buchanan and Aaron Byrd
title: N.Y.P.D. Says It Used Restraint During Protests. Here’s What the Videos Show.
description: Police officials say there were “isolated cases” of inappropriate force. But 64 videos show many attacks on protesters that appear unwarranted.
content: Police officials say there were “isolated cases” of inappropriate force. But 64 videos show many attacks on protesters that appear unwarranted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Josh Katz, Abby Goodnough and Margot Sanger-Katz
title: In Shadow of Pandemic, U.S. Drug Overdose Deaths Resurge to Record
description: After the first decrease in a quarter-century, in 2018, the number of deaths is again on the rise.
content: After the first decrease in a quarter-century, in 2018, the number of deaths is again on the rise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gus Wezerek
title: The Wealthy Can't Stop Not Paying Their Taxes
description: Budget cuts have left the I.R.S. unable to chase down wealthy tax evaders.
content: Budget cuts have left the I.R.S. unable to chase down wealthy tax evaders.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Living In ... The West Village
description: The neighborhood’s low-key, small-scale charms are gradually returning following the lockdown, although residential sales and prices are way down.
content: The neighborhood’s low-key, small-scale charms are gradually returning following the lockdown, although residential sales and prices are way down.

title: Clean Lines and Shiraz Vines in Rural Israel
description: This 1.5-acre farm in the Lower Galilee region of Israel, with a four-bedroom house and a separate guesthouse, is on the market for $4.3 million.
content: This 1.5-acre farm in the Lower Galilee region of Israel, with a four-bedroom house and a separate guesthouse, is on the market for $4.3 million.
source.name: The New York Times

title: What You Get for $1.3 Million
description: An artist’s studio and cottage in Greenport, N.Y.; a Tudor Revival house in Shaker Heights, Ohio; and a two-bedroom condo in Santa Monica, Calif.
content: An artist’s studio and cottage in Greenport, N.Y.; a Tudor Revival house in Shaker Heights, Ohio; and a two-bedroom condo in Santa Monica, Calif.

author: By The Associated Press
title: Governor of Oklahoma Says He Tested Positive for Coronavirus
description: Gov. Kevin Stitt of Oklahoma announced during a virtual news conference that he was the first governor to test positive for the coronavirus.
content: Gov. Kevin Stitt of Oklahoma announced during a virtual news conference that he was the first governor to test positive for the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Coronavirus Cases in U.S. Are ‘Unequivocally’ Rising, Fauci Says
description: Dr. Anthony S. Fauci said at a digital event at Georgetown University on Tuesday that there was “no doubt” of more infections.
content: Dr. Anthony S. Fauci said at a digital event at Georgetown University on Tuesday that there was “no doubt” of more infections.

author: By Felipe Neto
title: Trump Isn’t the Worst Pandemic President
description: Just ask Brazilians.
content: Just ask Brazilians.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: ‘We Are Dangerously Close,’ Lightfoot Warns Amid Rise in Cases
description: Mayor Lori Lightfoot of Chicago said that the city’s young people were not taking the virus seriously enough and suggested she would increase restrictions.
content: Mayor Lori Lightfoot of Chicago said that the city’s young people were not taking the virus seriously enough and suggested she would increase restrictions.
